title: Numbers Chapter 16 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Numbers chapter 16 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Numbers Chapter 16 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Numbers Chapter 16.

questions.question: Who led the rebellion against Moses and Aaron according to Numbers 16:1?
options: Korah
Moses
Aaron
Eleazar
questions.correctAnswer: Korah
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:1 states that Korah, son of Izhar, led the rebellion.

questions.question: How many princes of the assembly joined Korah in his rebellion as mentioned in Numbers 16:2?
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:2 says that 250 princes of the assembly joined Korah.

questions.question: What did Korah and his company claim about the congregation in Numbers 16:3?
options: All the congregation are holy
Only Moses is holy
Aaron is the only holy one
The congregation is sinful
questions.correctAnswer: All the congregation are holy
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:3 shows they claimed all the congregation are holy.

questions.question: What was Moses' reaction when he heard Korah's complaint in Numbers 16:4?
options: He fell upon his face
He shouted loudly
He ignored them
He fled
questions.correctAnswer: He fell upon his face
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:4 states Moses fell upon his face when he heard it.

questions.question: What did Moses instruct Korah and his company to bring for the test before the LORD in Numbers 16:6?
options: Censers with fire and incense
Bread and wine
Water and oil
Sacrificial lambs
questions.correctAnswer: Censers with fire and incense
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:6-7 explains Moses told them to bring censers with fire and incense.

questions.question: Which tribe did Korah belong to as mentioned in Numbers 16:8?
options: Levi
Reuben
Judah
Benjamin
questions.correctAnswer: Levi
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:8 refers to Korah as one of the sons of Levi.

questions.question: What reason did Dathan and Abiram give for refusing to come when Moses called them in Numbers 16:12?
options: They accused Moses of trying to kill them
They were sick
They were away from the camp
They were afraid of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: They accused Moses of trying to kill them
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:13 shows they said Moses brought them out to kill them in the wilderness.

questions.question: How did Moses respond when Dathan and Abiram refused to come in Numbers 16:15?
options: He was very angry and prayed to the LORD
He ignored them
He punished them immediately
He pleaded with the people
questions.correctAnswer: He was very angry and prayed to the LORD
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:15 states Moses was very wroth and prayed to the LORD about their offering.

questions.question: Where did Korah and his company stand with their censers before offering incense in Numbers 16:18?
options: At the door of the tabernacle of the congregation
On the top of the mountain
Inside the tabernacle
In the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: At the door of the tabernacle of the congregation
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:18 states they stood at the door of the tabernacle with Moses and Aaron.

questions.question: What happened to Korah and his company as a sign of God's judgment in Numbers 16:31-33?
options: The earth opened and swallowed them alive
They were burned by fire
They were exiled
They were forgiven
questions.correctAnswer: The earth opened and swallowed them alive
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:31-33 describes the earth opening and swallowing Korah and his company alive.

questions.question: True or False: According to Numbers 16:35, a fire from the LORD consumed the 250 men offering incense.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:35 confirms that fire from the LORD consumed the 250 men who offered incense.

questions.question: True or False: The censers of the sinners were destroyed and never used again according to Numbers 16:37-39.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:37-39 says the censers were made into plates to cover the altar as a memorial.

questions.question: True or False: After the judgment on Korah and his company, the congregation did not complain against Moses and Aaron according to Numbers 16:41.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:41 states the congregation murmured against Moses and Aaron.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Moses said, 'If these men die the common death of all men, or if they be visited after the visitation of all men; then the LORD hath not sent me.' (Numbers 16:29) The next sign would be if the earth ________ them.
options: opened her mouth and swallowed
covered them with dust
burned them with fire
flooded them with water
questions.correctAnswer: opened her mouth and swallowed
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:30 explains the earth opening her mouth and swallowing them would prove they provoked the LORD.

questions.question: According to Numbers 16:49, how many people died in the plague besides those who died about Korah's rebellion?
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:49 states that 14,700 died in the plague besides those who died about Korah.

medium.title: Numbers Chapter 16 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Numbers Chapter 16 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride and challenging church leadership. Based on Numbers 16, what biblical truth would you share about humility and respect for God's appointed leaders?
options: God chooses and appoints leaders, and challenging them is challenging His authority.
Leaders should always be obeyed without question regardless of their actions.
Everyone has equal authority and no one should lead over others.
Leadership is based on popularity among the people.
questions.correctAnswer: God chooses and appoints leaders, and challenging them is challenging His authority.
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:3, 5, and 11 show that Korah and his company challenged Moses and Aaron, but God had chosen them to lead. The passage teaches humility by recognizing God's choice in leadership rather than self-exalting.

questions.question: How does Numbers 16 teach us about the importance of obedience to God's commands in times of conflict within the church?
options: Obedience to God brings protection and vindication even in difficult trials.
Disobedience will always be overlooked if done for a good cause.
Personal opinions are more important than God's commands in conflict.
Ignoring God's instructions leads to peace.
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God brings protection and vindication even in difficult trials.
questions.explanation: In Numbers 16:21-22 and 46-48, Moses and Aaron obeyed God's instructions by separating from the congregation and making atonement, which stopped the plague and showed God's protection for obedience.

questions.question: A church member questions the exclusivity of priestly roles. Based on Numbers 16, what biblical principle about God’s designated roles in ministry would you explain?
options: Only those God appoints, like Aaron's descendants, may perform specific sacred duties.
Anyone can assume any ministry role without restriction.
Ministerial roles are based on personal ambition.
All members must rotate through all ministry tasks equally.
questions.correctAnswer: Only those God appoints, like Aaron's descendants, may perform specific sacred duties.
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:38-40 instruct that censers used by those who rebelled were made into a covering for the altar as a memorial to show that only Aaron’s seed may offer incense, emphasizing God's appointed roles.

questions.question: How does this chapter teach us about the consequences of rebellion and challenging God’s order in the church?
options: Rebellion against God’s order leads to severe judgment and separation from the congregation.
Rebellion is a minor issue and can be ignored.
God always forgives without discipline.
Leaders should tolerate rebellion to keep peace.
questions.correctAnswer: Rebellion against God’s order leads to severe judgment and separation from the congregation.
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:31-33 and 35 show that Korah and his company were swallowed by the earth and the 250 men offering incense were consumed by fire as judgment for rebellion.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to murmur and complain about God’s provision. According to Numbers 16, what practical lesson about contentment and trust can you share?
options: Complaining against God’s plan ignores His faithfulness and brings judgment.
It is acceptable to demand more from God.
God’s provision is incomplete and should be questioned.
Trust in God is optional when circumstances are difficult.
questions.correctAnswer: Complaining against God’s plan ignores His faithfulness and brings judgment.
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:13-14 records Dathan and Abiram’s complaints about not receiving land, yet God’s judgment followed due to their murmurings, teaching trust and contentment with God’s provision.

questions.question: What does Numbers 16 teach us about the role of intercessory prayer and making atonement during a crisis?
options: Intercession and atonement can bring God’s mercy and stop judgment.
Prayer has no effect on divine judgment.
Only the congregation can atone for sins, not leaders.
Atone only after judgment has ended.
questions.correctAnswer: Intercession and atonement can bring God’s mercy and stop judgment.
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:46-48 describes Aaron making atonement with incense to stop the plague, showing the power of intercessory prayer and obedience to God's command.

questions.question: True or False: According to Numbers 16, Moses was responsible for the rebellion and judgment against Korah and his company.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:15 shows Moses' innocence and that he asked the LORD not to accept their offerings, indicating that the judgment was due to rebellion, not Moses’ actions.

questions.question: True or False: The earth opened and swallowed Korah, Dathan, Abiram, and their households alive as a sign of God’s judgment in Numbers 16.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:32-33 clearly describes the earth opening and swallowing them alive as a demonstration of God's judgment.

questions.question: How does Numbers 16 teach us about the importance of trusting God’s timing and judgment when facing accusations or challenges to leadership?
options: Trust God to reveal His chosen leaders in His time without resorting to rebellion.
Take matters into your own hands immediately.
Ignore accusations without prayer or seeking God’s will.
Leadership challenges should be resolved by popular vote.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to reveal His chosen leaders in His time without resorting to rebellion.
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:5-7 shows Moses telling Korah that God will reveal His chosen servants, teaching trust in God’s timing rather than rebellion.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with jealousy towards church leaders. Based on Numbers 16, what biblical counsel about contentment and service would you offer?
options: Be content with the service God has called you to and serve faithfully.
Jealousy is a sign of spiritual growth.
Seek leadership by any means necessary.
Ignore God’s calling and pursue personal ambition.
questions.correctAnswer: Be content with the service God has called you to and serve faithfully.
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:8-10 reminds the sons of Levi they were separated by God for service and should not seek the priesthood, teaching contentment and faithfulness in God’s calling.

questions.question: What practical lesson about integrity and honesty in leadership can we learn from Moses' response to Korah’s rebellion?
options: Moses maintained integrity by declaring he took nothing from the rebels and pleaded for God’s judgment.
Moses retaliated unjustly against the rebels.
Moses ignored the rebellion to avoid conflict.
Moses manipulated the people to maintain power.
questions.correctAnswer: Moses maintained integrity by declaring he took nothing from the rebels and pleaded for God’s judgment.
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:15 shows Moses’ honest defense and prayer for God not to accept their offerings, demonstrating integrity and trust in God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Numbers 16, the censers used by the sinners were made into ________ for the altar as a memorial.
options: broad plates
golden idols
silver cups
stone tablets
questions.correctAnswer: broad plates
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:38-39 explains that the censers were made into broad plates for a covering of the altar as a sign to the children of Israel.

questions.question: How does Numbers 16 encourage perseverance through trials and trusting God’s justice?
options: God will vindicate His servants and punish rebellion in His perfect timing.
Trials are always a sign of failure.
Justice depends on human strength.
Endure silently without seeking God's help.
questions.correctAnswer: God will vindicate His servants and punish rebellion in His perfect timing.
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:29-31 shows Moses explaining that if God acts miraculously against the rebels, it confirms His justice, encouraging trust in God's timing during trials.

questions.question: According to Numbers 16, what role does prayer and intercession play in church life during times of crisis?
options: Prayer and intercession can bring mercy and prevent further judgment.
Prayer is ineffective in times of crisis.
Only leaders should pray, not the congregation.
Intercession is unnecessary if the crisis is severe.
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer and intercession can bring mercy and prevent further judgment.
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:46-48 illustrates Aaron’s intercession with incense to stop the plague, teaching the power of prayer in crises.

questions.question: How does this chapter teach about the importance of obedience to God’s holiness standards in family and community life?
options: Disobedience to God’s holiness can bring judgment on entire families and communities.
Only individual disobedience matters, not family or community.
Holiness standards are optional for believers.
Community consequences are unrelated to obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience to God’s holiness can bring judgment on entire families and communities.
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:27-33 shows that Korah’s entire household and followers were swallowed by the earth, illustrating consequences affecting families and community for disobedience.

questions.question: What message about gratitude and contentment can be drawn from Dathan and Abiram's complaints in Numbers 16?
options: Gratitude for God’s past blessings is essential rather than focusing on unmet desires.
Unmet desires justify rebellion.
Complaints always lead to blessings.
God owes us material blessings to prove His love.
questions.correctAnswer: Gratitude for God’s past blessings is essential rather than focusing on unmet desires.
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:13-14 records the complaints of Dathan and Abiram despite God’s deliverance, teaching the importance of gratitude over grumbling.

hard.title: Numbers Chapter 16 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Numbers Chapter 16.

questions.question: Who were the primary leaders that rose up against Moses and Aaron in Numbers 16?
options: Korah, Dathan, and Abiram
Miriam, Aaron, and Moses
Eleazar, Phinehas, and Joshua
Caleb, Joshua, and Korah
questions.correctAnswer: Korah, Dathan, and Abiram
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:1 identifies Korah, the son of Izhar, along with Dathan and Abiram as the chief instigators who challenged Moses and Aaron's leadership.

questions.question: What was the main accusation Korah and his company made against Moses and Aaron?
options: They took too much upon themselves and lifted themselves above the congregation
They failed to lead the people into the Promised Land
They neglected the offerings of the congregation
They allied with foreign gods
questions.correctAnswer: They took too much upon themselves and lifted themselves above the congregation
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:3 quotes Korah and his company claiming Moses and Aaron exalted themselves over the holy congregation, implying all are equally holy before the LORD.

questions.question: What was Moses' initial reaction upon hearing the rebellion from Korah and his followers?
options: He fell upon his face
He called for the Levites to fight
He immediately condemned them
He fled from the congregation
questions.correctAnswer: He fell upon his face
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:4 states that upon hearing the rebellion, Moses humbled himself by falling upon his face before the LORD, indicating a prayerful response.

questions.question: What test did Moses propose to prove whom the LORD had chosen to be holy and bring near to Him?
options: That they take censers with fire and incense and present them before the LORD
That they offer burnt offerings at the tabernacle
That they fast and pray for three days
That they build a special altar for the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: That they take censers with fire and incense and present them before the LORD
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:6-7 describes Moses instructing Korah and his followers to take censers with fire and incense to present before the LORD as a means to identify whom He has chosen.

questions.question: What significant theological theme is emphasized by Korah's claim that 'all the congregation are holy' before the LORD?
options: The universal holiness of Israel as a people
The exclusive priesthood of Aaron
The separation of Levites from Israel
The necessity of the tabernacle service
questions.correctAnswer: The universal holiness of Israel as a people
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:3 highlights Korah's argument that all Israelites are holy and that the LORD is among them, reflecting a theme of collective sanctity which contrasts with the Levitical priesthood's special role.

questions.question: Which sons of Reuben joined Korah in the rebellion and refused to come when summoned by Moses?
options: Dathan and Abiram
Eleazar and Phinehas
Nadab and Abihu
Gideon and Barak
questions.correctAnswer: Dathan and Abiram
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:12-14 recount how Dathan and Abiram, sons of Eliab from Reuben, refused Moses' call and challenged his leadership, highlighting tribal tensions.

questions.question: In Moses' message, what condition would prove that the LORD had not sent him?
options: If Korah and his company die the common death of all men
If the congregation accepts Korah's leadership
If the tabernacle is destroyed by fire
If the Levites refuse to serve
questions.correctAnswer: If Korah and his company die the common death of all men
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:29 explains Moses' challenge that if Korah and his followers died an ordinary death, then Moses' divine commission would be disproven.

questions.question: What miraculous event occurred immediately after Moses finished speaking to the congregation about Korah's rebellion?
options: The earth opened its mouth and swallowed Korah and his company
Fire consumed the entire camp
The tabernacle caught fire
Moses parted the Red Sea again
questions.correctAnswer: The earth opened its mouth and swallowed Korah and his company
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:31-32 narrate the earth opening and swallowing Korah, his household, and all his followers as a divine judgment and validation of Moses' leadership.

questions.question: How many men were consumed by fire from the LORD after the earth swallowed Korah and his immediate followers?
options: Two hundred and fifty
One hundred
Five hundred
Seventy
questions.correctAnswer: Two hundred and fifty
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:35 states that a fire came out from the LORD and consumed the 250 men who had offered incense in rebellion.

questions.question: What was done with the censers of the men who were consumed by fire, according to the LORD's instruction?
options: Made into broad plates for a covering of the altar
Thrown into the river
Used as trophies by the priests
Burned completely and scattered in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: Made into broad plates for a covering of the altar
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:38-39 reveals that the brass censers of the sinners were made into plates to cover the altar, serving as a memorial and warning to Israel.

questions.question: What warning was associated with the memorial made from the censers?
options: That no stranger who is not of Aaron's seed should offer incense
That all Levites must serve in the tabernacle
That the congregation should never murmur again
That the Promised Land will be forfeited
questions.correctAnswer: That no stranger who is not of Aaron's seed should offer incense
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:40 emphasizes the memorial's purpose to warn Israel that only descendants of Aaron may offer incense before the LORD, preventing a repeat of Korah's rebellion.

questions.question: True or False: After the judgment on Korah and his company, the entire congregation remained silent and submissive to Moses and Aaron.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:41 shows the congregation murmured against Moses and Aaron, accusing them of killing the people of the LORD, indicating ongoing unrest.

questions.question: What action did Aaron take to stop the plague that had begun among the congregation?
options: He took a censer with fire and incense and made atonement between the living and the dead
He led a fast and prayer session
He offered a burnt sacrifice
He commanded the people to leave the camp
questions.correctAnswer: He took a censer with fire and incense and made atonement between the living and the dead
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:46-48 describes Aaron taking incense and fire from the altar, entering the midst of the people, and making atonement which stopped the plague.

questions.question: How many people died in the plague besides those who died about the matter of Korah?
options: Fourteen thousand seven hundred
Ten thousand
One thousand
Twenty thousand
questions.correctAnswer: Fourteen thousand seven hundred
questions.explanation: Numbers 16:49 quantifies the death toll from the plague as fourteen thousand seven hundred, separate from those consumed by the earth.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the structure of Numbers 16, especially in the sequence of rebellion, divine judgment, and restoration?
options: Chiasm
Parable
Allegory
Prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: The chapter exhibits a chiastic structure where the rebellion (A), judgment (B), and restoration (A') mirror each other, highlighting central theological themes of divine authority and holiness.

questions.question: How does the episode of Korah's rebellion foreshadow New Testament themes of priesthood and mediation?
options: By emphasizing the exclusive priestly role of Aaron, it prefigures Christ as the ultimate high priest
By showing all Israelites as priests, it denies any special mediation
By focusing on tribal disputes, it ignores spiritual mediation
By promoting rebellion, it anticipates apostasy
questions.correctAnswer: By emphasizing the exclusive priestly role of Aaron, it prefigures Christ as the ultimate high priest
questions.explanation: The restriction of priestly duties to Aaron’s lineage in Numbers 16:40 anticipates the New Testament concept of Christ as the singular mediator and high priest (Hebrews 7), highlighting divine election and sanctification.

theological.title: Numbers Chapter 16 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Numbers Chapter 16 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who led the rebellion against Moses and Aaron, claiming that all the congregation were holy and questioning their leadership?
options: Korah, Dathan, and Abiram
Joshua and Caleb
Miriam and Aaron
Phinehas and Eleazar
questions.correctAnswer: Korah, Dathan, and Abiram
questions.explanation: Korah, along with Dathan and Abiram, led the rebellion against Moses and Aaron, claiming that all Israelites were holy and questioning their authority (Numbers 16:1-3). This challenge to divinely appointed leadership is consistent with the biblical theme of rebellion against God's chosen servants (e.g., 1 Samuel 15:23; Jude 1:9).

questions.question: What was Moses' response when he first heard Korah's challenge?
options: He fell upon his face
He immediately condemned them
He fled into the wilderness
He called for the people to stone them
questions.correctAnswer: He fell upon his face
questions.explanation: Upon hearing the rebellion, Moses fell upon his face in humility and intercession (Numbers 16:4). This reflects the biblical pattern of intercessory prayer in the face of sin (Exodus 32:11-14; Hebrews 7:25).

questions.question: What did God instruct Moses and the rebels to do to determine whom He had chosen?
options: Offer incense on censers before the LORD
Present burnt offerings at the altar
Fast and pray for three days
Bring the Ark of the Covenant to the assembly
questions.correctAnswer: Offer incense on censers before the LORD
questions.explanation: God instructed that Korah and his company take censers with fire and incense and present them before the LORD to see who He had chosen (Numbers 16:6-7). The use of incense symbolizes priestly intercession and divine acceptance (Exodus 30:7-8; Revelation 8:3-4).

questions.question: Why did Moses remind Korah and the Levites that God had separated them from the congregation?
options: To serve the tabernacle and minister before the congregation
To lead the people into battle
To become kings over Israel
To receive double portions of the land
questions.correctAnswer: To serve the tabernacle and minister before the congregation
questions.explanation: Moses reminded them that God had set the Levites apart to serve the tabernacle and minister before the congregation (Numbers 16:9-10). This highlights God's sovereign appointment of roles within the covenant community (Deuteronomy 10:8; Hebrews 7:26).

questions.question: How did Dathan and Abiram respond when Moses called them to discuss the rebellion?
options: They refused to come and accused Moses of killing them
They came willingly to plead their case
They confessed their sin and repented
They sought mediation through the elders
questions.correctAnswer: They refused to come and accused Moses of killing them
questions.explanation: Dathan and Abiram refused to come when called and accused Moses of bringing them out of a land flowing with milk and honey only to kill them in the wilderness (Numbers 16:12-14). This illustrates human rebellion against divine providence and leadership (Psalm 78:17-22; Acts 7:51).

questions.question: What sign did Moses say would confirm that the LORD had sent him?
options: If the earth opened and swallowed the rebels alive
If the rebels were stoned by the people
If fire consumed the entire camp
If the Ark of the Covenant moved
questions.correctAnswer: If the earth opened and swallowed the rebels alive
questions.explanation: Moses declared that if the rebels died a common death, he was not sent by the LORD; but if the earth opened and swallowed them alive, it would confirm God's judgment and Moses’ divine commission (Numbers 16:28-30). This miraculous judgment underscores God's holiness and justice (Psalm 94:23; Hebrews 12:29).

questions.question: What happened immediately after Moses finished speaking to the congregation about the judgment?
options: The earth opened and swallowed Korah, Dathan, Abiram, and their households
The people repented and sought forgiveness
The cloud of the LORD departed from the tabernacle
The rebels were imprisoned by Moses
questions.correctAnswer: The earth opened and swallowed Korah, Dathan, Abiram, and their households
questions.explanation: After Moses finished speaking, the earth split apart and swallowed the rebels and their households alive, and the earth closed over them, demonstrating God's immediate and decisive judgment against rebellion (Numbers 16:31-33). This typifies divine judgment against sin (Deuteronomy 11:6; Jude 1:7).

questions.question: What happened to the 250 men who offered incense as part of the rebellion?
options: They were consumed by fire from the LORD
They escaped unharmed
They were forgiven after repenting
They were exiled from the camp
questions.correctAnswer: They were consumed by fire from the LORD
questions.explanation: The 250 men who offered unauthorized incense were consumed by fire from the LORD, illustrating the seriousness of approaching God apart from His ordained priesthood (Numbers 16:35; Leviticus 10:1-2; Hebrews 10:28).

questions.question: What purpose did God give for making the censers of the sinners into broad plates on the altar?
options: To serve as a memorial and warning against unauthorized priesthood
To be melted down for temple utensils
To be sold for the tabernacle upkeep
To decorate the tabernacle curtains
questions.correctAnswer: To serve as a memorial and warning against unauthorized priesthood
questions.explanation: God instructed that the censers be made into broad plates for the altar as a memorial to warn that no unauthorized person should approach to offer incense, emphasizing the holiness required in worship (Numbers 16:38-40; Exodus 28:36; Hebrews 7:11-14).

questions.question: What was the reaction of the congregation the day after the judgment on Korah and his company?
options: They murmured against Moses and Aaron, accusing them of killing the people of the LORD
They praised God for His justice
They immediately obeyed Moses without complaint
They appointed new leaders
questions.correctAnswer: They murmured against Moses and Aaron, accusing them of killing the people of the LORD
questions.explanation: Despite God's judgment, the congregation murmured against Moses and Aaron, accusing them of killing the people, demonstrating human unbelief and resistance to divine discipline (Numbers 16:41; Psalm 106:25; Hebrews 3:16-19).

questions.question: How did God respond to the congregation's murmuring after the rebellion?
options: He declared He would consume them and sent a plague
He immediately forgave them
He sent manna to provide for them
He caused the Ark to leave the camp
questions.correctAnswer: He declared He would consume them and sent a plague
questions.explanation: God expressed His anger and declared He would consume the congregation, resulting in a plague that began among the people (Numbers 16:44-46). This shows God's holiness and judgment on persistent sin (Exodus 32:35; 2 Samuel 24:15; 1 Corinthians 10:10).

questions.question: What role did Aaron play during the plague among the congregation?
options: He made atonement with incense and stood between the dead and the living
He fled the camp to save himself
He prayed silently without action
He led the people in battle against rebels
questions.correctAnswer: He made atonement with incense and stood between the dead and the living
questions.explanation: Aaron took a censer with fire and incense, made atonement for the people, and stood between the dead and the living, which stopped the plague (Numbers 16:46-48). This prefigures Christ as our High Priest who intercedes (Hebrews 9:11-12; Romans 8:34).

questions.question: How many people died in the plague besides those who died in the matter of Korah?
options: Fourteen thousand seven hundred
Ten thousand
Twenty thousand
Five thousand
questions.correctAnswer: Fourteen thousand seven hundred
questions.explanation: The text states that 14,700 died in the plague besides those who died in Korah's rebellion, illustrating the severe consequences of corporate sin and rebellion (Numbers 16:49; Exodus 32:28; Psalm 95:10).

questions.question: What does Numbers 16 teach about God's attribute in relation to sin and rebellion?
options: God is holy and just, executing judgment on rebellion
God is indifferent to human disobedience
God tolerates sin without consequence
God condones all challenges to leadership
questions.correctAnswer: God is holy and just, executing judgment on rebellion
questions.explanation: This chapter repeatedly shows God’s holiness and justice in judging Korah’s rebellion and the unauthorized approach to Him (Numbers 16:31-35; Deuteronomy 32:4; Isaiah 6:3; Hebrews 12:29).

questions.question: What theological lesson about God's chosen mediators and priesthood is highlighted in this chapter?
options: Only those God appoints may approach Him in worship
All believers may freely offer incense
Priesthood is based on human merit
Leadership is interchangeable among tribes
questions.correctAnswer: Only those God appoints may approach Him in worship
questions.explanation: The chapter teaches that only God’s chosen priests, descendants of Aaron, may offer incense and serve at the altar, underlining the doctrine of divine appointment and mediation (Numbers 16:38-40; Exodus 28:1; Hebrews 5:1-4).

questions.question: How does the judgment of Korah and his company foreshadow the ultimate rejection of sin and rebellion in the New Testament?
options: It prefigures the final judgment where all rebellion against God is punished
It shows that rebellion is always overlooked
It suggests sin has no real consequences
It teaches that leaders must be overthrown
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures the final judgment where all rebellion against God is punished
questions.explanation: The judgment on Korah’s rebellion foreshadows God’s ultimate judgment on sin and rebellion as revealed in the New Testament (Revelation 20:11-15; Hebrews 10:26-31; Romans 1:18), affirming God’s righteous governance over His people.
